Author: cbg#7638
Content:
Hello! I've started looking into DayZ modding with no prior experience except - well - coding for many years. I'm unsure about the process of setting up, testing and publishing a mod. Without official documentation, from the internet I basically gather 2 main approaches: 
1) Creating a custom mission that can include code that overrides internal functions/classes 
2) Changing scripts themselves and package them into .pbo files to get them back into the game (a rather obscure process for me still) 

Can someone explain to me the differences between these approaches? What would be the preferred way to do it for mods heavily based on scripting and changing internal mechanics? As opposed to let's say more configuration based mods? Also it's not clear to me if changes have to be made on server side, client side or both and how these 2 relate to each other/are synced in general. Would appreciate any enlightment 😃

Author: kegan.eth
Content: @cbg  missions cannot override internal functions or classes

Author: kegan.eth
Content: it can only call them

Author: kegan.eth
Content:
For example, if I wanted to give the player a gun, I can just call some functions on the player from the mission.
If I wanted to make it so their gun has no recoil, I would need to modify internal functions as no functionality is built for that. A mission cannot do this, only packed PBO mods

Author: kegan.eth
Content: The client/server interection is actually a little more difficult to wrap minds around. When starting, the general rule of thumb I'd give out is that 9 times out of 10, the server is where the code needs to be. Trying to think of some client side stuff in BR, I think its entirely changes or tweaks to the clients UI logic at the moment.

Author: cbg#7638
Content:
Thx a lot Kegan! So PBO is the way to go?
I got the other idea from looking at the structure of DayZCommunityOfflineMode which is based on a mission template. There is a folder "patches" which includes "DebugMonitor.c" and "PluginLifespan.c", containing classes DebugMonitorPatched and PluginLifespanPatched which apparently override part of the functionality of their parent classes (which seem to be internal). These patched versions get initialized in init.c and used from there. Am I misunderstanding something here?
For the PBO case: Is there some information somewhere on how to correctly package scripts and how to get them into the game? I'd like to try out some things already but first I'd need to know how to even test my stuff ^^

Author: kegan.eth
Content:
@cbg  COM is a great showcase of the power of a mission file, but those tools will not work in multiplayer, that is why the authors are creating a new version CommunityOnlineTools, that will work in multiplayer. 
With COM, it is not overriding the base game functionality, for those files you specified, they are actually created in the mission, and because COM is a mission file, it can choose to launch different functionality instead. 

Further, with multiplayer, I don't think anyone has figured out how to make the mission file run code on the clients, if it even can. So with missions you would be limited to changing only server-sided code. So custom UI would not be possible.

What you see in COM is the use of "extended" in the classes, which works just like any other Object Oriented language for the most part (Not entirely, there are weaknesses in DayZs version).
With PBOs, you also get the "modded" tag for classes, which actually overwrite the base game code, causing all of DayZ, even the internal parts, to run your modded code over the original.

I don't know of any tutorials specifically for DayZ yet, but there is a lot of information on this discord spread out that you can dig for! 😄

Author: kegan.eth
Content: One last thing, mission files are good for small tweaks. Anything large may be more complex to do with a mission than with PBOs.

Author: kegan.eth
Content: BR could probably be done with a mission for example, but we would still be in development 😄
